intro: Tapura carinata, commonly known as the mountain holly, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to cool, moist climates. Its leaves are leathery and dark green, while its flowers range from white to pink, blooming in late spring to early summer. Tapura carinata is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens in temperate regions.
